Params[3]: Winter. The first encounter between Bella and the 17-year-old Noan—
Noan has witnessed the conflicts within Asslam slowly come to a boiling point during the years he has served on the Cargo Crew, a festering wound that tests the boundaries of the people and the law.
To stand a chance against the guards from the upper level, Rachel has finally found several weapon suppliers who are willing to work with her after a long period of searching and hard work.
Still, there are many desperate people in the lower level who are willing to snitch on them like Bancroft did.
The Cargo Crew has to hide the weapons they have procured in different cargos, sending them all across the world with their trucks to keep their plan safe.
They will have to wait for the right time before retrieving the weapons.
Hi! Captain Rachel told me to come here and collect the remaining Blessing Boxes. Is Mr. Bethe here?
My grandfather went to sleep after finishing his work. You're from the Cargo Crew? Where's Rachel?
She's busy with something else, so she asked me to come this time.
Huh...
I've heard Rachel's distrustful of the people around her. I wasn't expecting it to be so bad that she's making a child captain.
She gauges Noan's height with her hand.
Have you considered that I might be a genius prodigy?
Noan no longer feels bothered the way he did when he was younger when he hears someone challenge him. He changes the topic with a smile.
If Mr. Bethe isn't here, maybe you can help me with the supplies instead?
Sure. You mean the last batch of "merch," right?
Right.
The weapon parts and ammo have all been dispersed among the unsold Blessing Boxes according to Rachel's specifications.
Will they stay hidden?
The guards are used to seeing these boxes. They'll open the containers to inspect the other packages, but they're too lazy to open the Blessing Boxes one by one to check what's inside.
Every time Rachel purchases a new order of weaponry, she disguises them as unsold Blessing Boxes and hides them in different refugee bases.
Just like how these "Pandora Boxes" were the aristocrats' tool to destroy the lower level, they are now the Cargo Crew's instrument to secure power for the rebellion.
As long as you guys know what you're doing.
Not counting the ones with the "merch," we somehow sold 31 of these boxes. Can't believe there are still people who fall for these scams.
They're selling much worse than they used to. No one's making them anymore on the train. This is the last batch remaining.
What about the other items we're selling here?
They're almost out, including your moonshine. Here's the list. You'll find our fee on it.
Thanks. And the thing we mentioned last time...
My grandfather said no. The way he put it, you'll only drag him into your fight if he joins you. You'll be asking for supplies or refuge or something else... he'll never hear the end of it.
Further involvement will only put this base at risk. Selling you guys weapons is as far as we go.
...Alright. I understand.
Get on with your work. The bees are also done with rebuilding the base last night, so take them with you.
The woman looks toward where Bumblebee is, sighing with anguish and disgust.
...They're also a mess, that lot.
Noan and Cargo Crew 08 walk toward where Bumblebee is resting and find the upper-level guards that usually oversee the operations here are nowhere to be found.
The Bumblebee members all look exhausted and sad, their heads lowered.
Blood splatters on the ground near them, telling the same story once again.
...They did this?
Who else? Someone couldn't finish the crazy amount of work, so they were going to deduct our pay.
Our captain was pissed, so he started fighting with the guards.
Couldn't finish your work again?
Finish my ***!
Shouting angrily with his hoarse voice, the Bumblebee captain stands up, his hand covering his injury.
Their CPF wasn't completely fixed when we worked on the area. We didn't have enough protective gear, but the "dickheads" didn't give a ****.
The CPF always fails a few months before we come here to rebuild. We're gonna die if we arrive early, and if we arrive late—who's going to let us arrive late?
A hulking "dickhead" arrived in the morning and told us to fix the house on the left first. Then another "dickhead" visited in the evening and told us to prioritize the farm.
They're both subcontracting the work they took and getting commissions from them. They don't care how much work there is!
So many folks on the train could use a meal, but they wouldn't bring extra hands, so they wouldn't have the extra mouths to feed.
I was complaining about the lack of work for all the hungry folks on the train four years ago, but it's worse now. Those who stayed are starving, and those who came out here are worked to death!

Time was short, and we had to crunch—two weeks ago, the CPF at the reconstruction site broke down in the middle of the night. We were all working underground, so no one noticed it when the signal light turned red.

The engineer at the base spotted it and contacted the "dickheads" overseeing the work. Guess what? Those drunkards were sleeping, and they didn't bother to do anything! So the engineer thought we weren't there!
By the time the "dickheads" woke up in the middle of the day, we already had four infected! We even had to inject the serums ourselves!
They're like that every time! Good luck finding them to confirm anything on time!
Unless they're here to fine us! Suddenly they'll have a detailed list of every little mistake we've made! Some of the things they're charging us don't even make sense!
We thought there'd still be something left when all's said and done, but no! One guy didn't fill his quota, and now they're not paying any one of us!
Ha! What did Captain say when we left the train? "If we need to crunch, we'll crunch. At least they picked us, and we won't have to starve."
With what they're fining us, we somehow have to pay them back.
I was reasoning with them, but the "dickheads" were like, "At least Akdilek gave us two meals a day," and they threatened to turn off the CPF and water filter where we rest if we keep complaining!
Can you stand that?
How is it different from murdering us themselves if they stop the CPF and the water filter?
So we started punching!
Could you beat them?
They might be armed, but we got the number. Still... some of us inevitably got hurt...
Where are the guards?
Gone. They weren't going to throw their lives away.
We should've followed him and crushed his head with our hammers!
Didn't you see him opening his terminal? They wouldn't just indict us if we kept fighting! What would happen when we go back?
How many are hurt?
Six... Seven, counting him.

Noan quickly walks further inside and finds six people lying on makeshift wooden beds. The ones slightly hurt are dressing their injuries with dirty rags, while others are surrounding the two that were heavily wounded.
One of them is unconscious with a gun wound in the stomach right on the liver. The other one is still awake, luckily, with a few broken ribs.
Is there anything they won't do?!
Help them first. There should still be some meds in the supplies we're bringing back.
Those are our wares. How are we going to explain to the guards if we're short? We're going to get punished too.
...I'll cover the loss.
Do you have a lot of supplies with you? These people don't have anything to give you in return. The most valuable thing they have is their lives.
Listen, Four-Eyes—not that I don't want to save them. It's just...
...I know.

Being part of the Cargo Crew used to be an enviable position for the Bumblebee. With the more established structure, Cargo Crew members can just make a living underneath a leader who cares about them.
But, like the Bumblebee, the Cargo Crew can hardly look out for themselves nowadays, not to mention other people.
Help the heavily wounded first. Supplies are scarce, but they've also helped us in the past.
No way we can save the one shot in the gut!
Then we have five we can save.
But...!
Listen to Four-Eyes here. It's also what Rachel would've wanted. Not to mention that we're almost "ready."
...You're right. Let's go.
The Cargo Crew members gesture to each other before running toward the warehouse where the wares are.
Thanks.
You said seven. Where's the other one?
You mean ol' Ed? He didn't make it...
He was the one who couldn't finish the job. Those ******* guards... Ed was old and sick, and they still chose him to work out here!
...Where is he?
The Bumblebee captain points at the ruins to the west, his expression livid.
You don't want to go there. He died from an infection.
Noan? Hey!
Let him go. Sigh... Ol' Ed took care of him when he was young. He was the one who helped Noan see Julie one last time before she died.
Tch. Don't blame me if he's infected!
With no way to express his anger, the captain's fist hits the wall with a dull thud. As its echo fades, everyone hears a woman's heartbreaking cry coming from behind.
The person with the gun wound is no longer in pain. Surrounded by his friends and companions, he has left this cold, uncaring world behind.
By the time the Bumblebee has finished burying their dead and boarded the trucks with their belongings and grief, Noan is met with another bad news.
...What's wrong?
The Cargo Crew member in charge of inspecting the wares is standing next to a pile of collapsed crates, staring at the blood flowing out from underneath in panic.
The upper-level guards were checking the goods and found a few Blessing Boxes too packed...
I was going to distract them, but the crane in the warehouse suddenly moved and knocked down the crates on top.

The Cargo Crew member points at the control panel in the distance, where a woman is sitting quietly with her head lowered. She is not looking at the bloody scene, nor does she look like she intends to leave her seat.
She is... the wife of the person who just passed. The one who got shot in the gut.
What should we do? That's three dead guards under those crates. How the hell are we going to explain it?
It was an accident. Their deaths have nothing to do with the Blessing Boxes or any personal quarries. That's what we're going to say.
Will the other guards believe us?
I'll testify.
I'm also partially responsible. I should have packed the Blessing Boxes more carefully.
Thank you, but this would have happened even if they hadn't discovered the boxes.
He sighs, looking at the crying woman at the control panel.
Power secured by violence will one day be taken by violence.
It's sorted?
Yes. You'll find your payment inside warehouse A1. Thanks again. We've got to go.
Are you alright? You look like you're going to break down any second.
Break down? Me?
Is there someone else here?
Hearing her words, Noan finally notices the dull pain in his chest.
...I'm fine. I'm just exhausted.
Is that all?
Your team told me that one of the dead bees was someone who took care of you since you were young.
—How could that be all?
Even though he has seen his share of deaths, it is not something he can get used to.
But...
We're standing within a rushing riptide right now. Any careless mistake will bring the thousands of folks in the Cargo Crew down with us.
There are too many people we have to save. The only way we can turn this around is by tackling the root of the problem.
You're a captain and a core member of the Cargo Crew now, so every move you make will be monitored. Do not do anything on impulse—be patient! Act like a grown-up!
Never mind. It's impressive that you're still functioning and doing your job as it is. Most can't get into the Cargo Crew at your age, not to mention become a captain.
...Thanks for your compliments.
Tch... Already smiling, are we? Are you mellow, or are you just cold-hearted?
Neither. I'm busy. I don't have time to be sad.
...I can kinda see why Rachel trusts you on a job this important.
There are still some things I'm curious about, but I'm not sure if it's my place to ask.
What is it?
I've been told that supplies are even more scarce on the train than in refugee bases like ours. How has Rachel managed to find so many things to trade?
No idea. Rachel has her way, and she won't tell me.
How likely do you think you'll win?
No idea. There's still a lot we aren't sure about and many we don't trust. Guessing now is a fool's errand.
That was the last batch of weapons. When are you going to act?
No idea. That's up to Rachel.
You have no idea about anything, and you still carry on. Are you that eager to die?
No. There's a reason Captain Rachel doesn't tell anyone any details.

The aristocrats have known what we're up to for a while. Failing to find any evidence, all they can do is pressure us and keep searching. Should they get ahold of anything, the consequences will be dire.

If you're curious, why don't you agree with Captain Rachel's proposal? Mr. Bethe and you are both merchants she's collaborated with secretly for a long time. Perhaps she'll make an exception and tell you her plan?
Having a refugee base to support us continuously will give us something reliable to fall back on. You've already planned to cover for us, after all.
Grandfather said no, and that means no. You can owe me a favor for covering for you. It has nothing to do with my grandfather or the base.
She looks down in silence briefly.
Grandfather said you are destined to fail. You're all one step away from your graves.
Any instability at Akdilek will impact the bases greatly. If you all lose, our trades will also be affected.
Not to mention the elderly on the train, and the other kids like you...
Better a corpse than a servant and an accomplice to those aristocrats.
...Is that something a kid your age gets to say?
That's what everyone else says. I just take after them.
Speaking of which, everyone on your team is older than you. Do they listen to you?
They don't have to. I only made captain because I got along with the people around me.
They're not impressed with what I can do—they simply support and trust me as their comrade. I listen to them as often as they listen to me. We're all equal.
Equal...? I was expecting more arrogance from a kid like you! How old are you?
18 next summer.
And I thought you were no older than 14. I guess you're still waiting for your growth spurt... Well, do your best and live. You still owe me one.
Thanks. I appreciate it.
Nodding sincerely, Noan has no idea how he will come to regret his promise in the future.
What's your name?
I'm Bella. Last name's Bethe, like my grandfather. Bella Bethe.
Cool name. I guess I'll call you Bebe—
Bella gives him a solid knock on his head before he can finish.
I guess Rachel didn't tell you not to call me that.
She only ever talked about old Mr. Bethe, Miss Bethe.
Bethe is fine. I'm older than you but not old enough for honorifics.
Alright, Bethe.
—That will be his first and last time to call Bella by that name.
Noan is prepared to make any sacrifices. He never expects to see her again.
I'll see you around.
With those words that even he himself finds improbable, Noan waves and turns around, leaving with a smile that he has put on so many times on occasions like this.
Bella only remembers that there was something she forgot to ask when Noan's figure disappeared from her sight.
...What's his name again?
